simplePliCTerm.definition.Metadata: Information about the collections of records.
simplePliCTerm.definition.dateStamp: The date the metadata document was created or modified.
simplePliCTerm.definition.citation: A single citation for use when citing the dataset.
simplePliCTerm.definition.dataset: The dataset element is a wrapper for all other elements relating to a single dataset.
simplePliCTerm.definition.resourceLogoUr: The URI of an icon/logo symbolizing the project.
simplePliCTerm.definition.References: This element is from the EOL standard.
simplePliCTerm.definition.TaxonRecordID: A unique identifier inside the database, for the species record.
simplePliCTerm.definition.taxonConceptID: An identifier for the taxonomic concept to which the record refers - not for the nomenclatural details of a taxon.
simplePliCTerm.definition.GlobalUniqueId: According to Darwin Core: An Uniform Resource Name (URN) used as an unique identifier of the taxon record.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Abstract: General description of the taxon. This concept could point out any information about the taxon. Its main goal is summarize the most relevant or attractive characteristics of this taxon to the general public.
simplePliCTerm.definition.RecordMetadata: This element includes the information about the Version, Revision,the language and target audiences of the Taxon Record
simplePliCTerm.definition.Language: Language used to write the species information, ISO 639-2 according to GBIF Metadata Profile, Reference Guide http://links.gbif.org/gbif_metadata_profile_guide_en_v1.
simplePliCTerm.definition.TargetAudience: Users to which the information is addressed. The defined audiences are: Biodiversity researchers, teachers and students, decision makers, professionals from another areas and general public.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Audience: Repetitive concept where the target audiences are written one by one. The recommended controlled vocabulary list includes: Expert, Knowledgeable and General.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Version: Number and date of the current version.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Revision: Creators, revision status and dates of the entire data collection.
simplePliCTerm.definition.associatedPart: It provides the full name of other people, organizations, or positions who should be associated with the resource  Quick reference: agentWithRoleType
simplePliCTerm.definition.pubDate: The date on which the resource was published This type is the union of the built-in types for year and date.
simplePliCTerm.definition.created: The date on which the resource was created.
simplePliCTerm.definition.NomenclatureAn: Standard information for every known taxon: Taxon Record Name, Synomyms, Common Names, Hierarchy, Misc. Details and Ancillary Data.
simplePliCTerm.definition.TaxonRecordNam: Complete information about the name of the taxon.
simplePliCTerm.definition.ScientificName: Canonical name enforcing strict inclusion of only nomenclatural information - nottaxonomic information. The name entered here must comply with rules and recommendations of the international nomenclatural code pertaining to the organisms (Zoological, Botanical, of Cultivated Pants, or Bacteriological).
simplePliCTerm.definition.SynonymsAtomiz: Synonyms element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Publishedln: A link to where this name was first published.
simplePliCTerm.definition.SynonymStatus: This is equivalent and probably replaceable by dc:nomenclaturalStatus http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/index.htm#nomenclaturalStatus
simplePliCTerm.definition.CommonNamesAto: A list of common names, in alphabetic order, optionally followed by language and region where it is used. If language or region is omitted, it is assumed to be unknown.
simplePliCTerm.name.Name: Nombre común
simplePliCTerm.definition.Name: The name of the common name.
simplePliCTerm.comments.Name: Example: Polar Bear
simplePliCTerm.definition.Language: Language used to write the species information, ISO 639-2 according to GBIF Metadata Profile.
simplePliCTerm.definition.UsedIn: Location where de common name is used.
simplePliCTerm.definition.UsedBy: Sometimes names used by one group of people are adopted by another.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Hierarchy: Hierarchical categories. Modified from Linnean Core. Option: fill all or principal ranks and optionally provide keys.
simplePliCTerm.definition.taxonRank: The taxonomic rank of the most specific name in the scientificName. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.
simplePliCTerm.definition.specificEpithe: The name of the first or species epithet of the scientificName
simplePliCTerm.definition.infraSpecificE: The name of the lowest or terminal infraspecific epithet of the scientificName, excluding any rank designation.
simplePliCTerm.definition.higherClassifi: A list (concatenated and separated) of taxa names terminating at the rank immediately superior to the taxon referenced in the taxon record. Recommended best practice is to order the list starting with the highest rank and separating the names for each rank with a semi-colon (';').
simplePliCTerm.definition.TaxonomicDescr: Description of Taxon: Brief description, Full description, Identification keys and Ancillary Data.
simplePliCTerm.definition.BriefDescripti: Brief description, presented in a simple technical language, to distinguish the species from other close or similar ones.
simplePliCTerm.definition.FullDescriptio: Complete and detailed account of the taxonomic and systematic characters, i.e. those that define and allow to recognize an organism.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Identification: Tool for the identification of organisms, comprising a series of steps, each of which represents a question about one or more characters of the organism. Each step offers multiple alternatives, choosing one of them will lead us to the next step until reaching, finally, the name of the organism. Most of the keys only   offer two alternatives, the so called dichotomous keys. A taxon can include an identification key for the subordinate taxa.
simplePliCTerm.comments.IdentificationKe: Example: The register of a genre will include the keys of the species shown in this genre, and the register of a species will include the keys of infraspecific ranks (in the case of plants: subspecies, variety, forms...).
simplePliCTerm.comments.Keys: Example: In plants: subspecies, varieties, forms
simplePliCTerm.definition.NaturalHistory: Most relevant description about the species: Life Form, Life Cycle, Reproduction, Annual Cycles, Feeding, Dispersal, Behavior, Interactions, Molecular Data, Migratory, Ecological Significance, Miscellaneous Details, Environmental Envelope and Ancillary Data.
simplePliCTerm.definition.LifeForm: General appearance. Characteristic mode of growth or occurrence associated to the environment, particularly for plants. Comprising the size, shape, texture and orientation.  A controlled vocabulary is recommended (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raunki%C3%A6r_plant_life-form).
simplePliCTerm.definition.LifeFormUnstru: LifeForm element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.LifeFormAtomiz: In DetailClass Value field a controlled vocabulary is recommended.
simplePliCTerm.comments.LifeFormAtomized: Example: Tree, shrubs, herbs (Raunkiær plant life-form system).
simplePliCTerm.definition.LifeCycle: Life history of a living organism: The sequence of life stages that an organisms undergoes from the fertilized zygote to reproduction ending with the generation of the offspring, or stages through which an organism passes.
simplePliCTerm.definition.LifeCycleUnstr: LifeCycle element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Reproduction: All data related to the generation of offspring.  A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
simplePliCTerm.definition.ReproductionUn: Reproduction element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.AnnualCycles: Set of changes or events that recurrently take place at the same time of year and are influenced by seasonal and interannual climate variations. For example: reproduction, flowering, fruiting, emergence of insects, etc. Also called   phenology, mainly in plants. In the case of migration, it only makes reference to the timing; other data about this are gathered in MigratoryData.
simplePliCTerm.definition.AnnualCyclesUn: AnnualCyles element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Event: An action that occurs at some location during some time. A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
simplePliCTerm.definition.startTimeInter: The date-time or interval at which an event starts. Recommended best practice is to use an encoding scheme, such as ISO 8601:2004(E). A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
simplePliCTerm.comments.startTimeInterva: Example: 1963-03-08T14:07-0600' is 8 Mar 1963 2:07pm in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC, '2009-02-20T08:40Z' is 20 Feb 2009 8:40am UTC, '1809-02-12' is 12 Feb 1809, '1906-06' is Jun 1906, '1971' is just that year, '2007-03-01T13:00:00Z/2008-05-11T15:30:00Z' is the interval between 1 Mar 2007 1pm UTC and 11 May 2008 3:30pm UTC, '2007-11-13/15' is the interval between 13 Nov 2007 and 15 Nov 2007.
simplePliCTerm.definition.endTimeInterva: The date-time or interval at which an event ends. Recommended best practice is to use an encoding scheme, such as ISO 8601:2004(E). A controlled vocabulary is recommended
simplePliCTerm.comments.endTimeInterval: Example: 1963-03-08T14:07-0600' is 8 Mar 1963 2:07pm in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC, '2009-02-20T08:40Z' is 20 Feb 2009 8:40am UTC, '1809-02-12' is 12 Feb 1809, '1906-06' is Jun 1906, '1971' is just that year, '2007-03-01T13:00:00Z/2008-05-11T15:30:00Z' is the interval between 1 Mar 2007 1pm UTC and 11 May 2008 3:30pm UTC, '2007-11-13/15' is the interval between 13 Nov 2007 and 15 Nov 2007
simplePliCTerm.definition.Feeding: Information related to the food supply for the development and sustenance of the individual and/or its offspring.
simplePliCTerm.definition.FeedingUnstruc: Feeding element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.type: Primary diet source.  A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
simplePliCTerm.comments.type: Example: Autotrophs, Heterotrophs-Herbivores, Heterotrophs-Carnivores, Heterotrophs-Omnivores, Heterotrophs-Saprophagous, Heterotrophs-Detitivores...
simplePliCTerm.definition.Strategy: Tactic used to obtain energy or nutrients.  A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
simplePliCTerm.comments.Strategy: Example: Chemosynthetic organisms,Photosynthetic organisms,Parasites,Decomposers,Suspension feeders,Substrate feeders, Grazers,Fluid-feeders,Predators...
simplePliCTerm.definition.StrategyRemark: Information notes about specific feeding strategies.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Dispersal: The permanent spreading of individuals away from each other not including return. Dispersal determines the range over which genetic mixing occurs, and thus, the degree of homogeneity and inbreeding in a population.
simplePliCTerm.definition.DispersalUnstr: Dispersal element in text block format
simplePliCTerm.definition.Purpose: Makes reference to any data being measured.
simplePliCTerm.comments.Type: Example: Zoochory, Anemochory, Hydrochory, Barochory, Autochory
simplePliCTerm.comments.StructureDispers: Example: Seed, Fruit, Vegetative structure, Spores, Gametes, Eggs, Offspring and Individuals
simplePliCTerm.definition.Behavior: Responses, reactions or movements made by an organism in a particular situation.
simplePliCTerm.definition.BehaviorUnstru: Behavior element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Interactions: Mutual or reciprocal actions or influences. For example, predation, parasitism, mutualism, etc. Relations with products grown and stored by man (plagues) are also included.
simplePliCTerm.definition.InteractionUns: Interactions element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.InteractionSpe: Information category concerning relations between resources (instances or records, such as Occurrences, Taxa, Locations, Events,...).
simplePliCTerm.comments.InteractionSpeci: Example: * 'Apis mellifera polinates Cistus ladanifer' * relationshipOfResource: polinator * resourceID: the id of the taxon of the record * relatedResourceID: identifier for a related resource
Example: InteractionSpeciesType: 'ecological role' . Others could be 'food chain' and associate terms: feeds on, patasites, decomposes,…) >
simplePliCTerm.definition.MolecularData: Information about the chemical structures and biological processes at the molecular level: DNA and proteins sequences, protein structures, expression profiles of genes protein domains, families of genes, mutations, polymorphisms, involvement in disease, ... Undeveloped. Placeholder for connecting with standards developed by specialists. For example, Standards for Data Exchange and Management from Scalalife (http://www.scalalife.eu/content/data)
simplePliCTerm.definition.MolecularDataU: MolecularData element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Related to: Specifies to which PlinianCore term the information contained under MolecularDataAtomized refers to. The controlled vocabulary is the rest of the PlinianCore elements.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Migratory: The regular, usually seasonal, movement of all or part of an animal population to and from a given area, which can occur in variable periods of time and even involve more than one generation.
simplePliCTerm.definition.MigratoryUnstr: Migratory element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.MigratoryAtomi: Migratory element in structured format. A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Season: Time of year in which a species migrates.
simplePliCTerm.definition.EcologicalSign: Role of the species in ecosystems. Could be referred to its position in food chains, ecosystems services or its use as bioindicators.
EcologicalSignificance element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.EnvironmentalE: Set of environmental conditions within which it is believed that the species can persist; i.e. where its environmental requirements can be satisfied.
EnvironmentalEnvelope element in text block format.

Structured information category concerning measurements, facts, characteristics, or assertions about a resource (instances or records, such as Occurrence, Taxon, Location, Event).  A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
simplePliCTerm.comments.EnvironmentalEnv: Example: Environmental range in which the organism lives (e.g. annual precipitation/average/450/mm)
simplePliCTerm.definition.Invasiveness: According to GSIN the information about invasive exotic species that could threaten native species, their habitats, and negatively impact human health, the economy (i.e. tourism, agriculture), and native ecosystems. http://www.gisin.org/cwis438/websites/GISINDirectory/Tech/Model_info.php?ModelID=1&WebSiteID=4
simplePliCTerm.definition.InvasivenessUn: Invasiveness element in block text format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.origin: Whether the species is considered to be native to a particular location or not.
simplePliCTerm.definition.presence: There is supporting evidence to show the species is present within the valid date
simplePliCTerm.definition.persistence: How successful the organism is at surviving and reproducing
simplePliCTerm.definition.distribution: Whether the species is limited to a local area or covers vast tracks of land or water
simplePliCTerm.definition.harmful: Whether the organism is considered harmful. Invasive Species should return 'Harmful=Yes' and 'Origin=Nonindigenous'. More detailed 'harm' information is dealt with in the ImpactStatus Data Model.
simplePliCTerm.definition.modified: This is the last date that the record changed on in the format YYYY-MM-DD. This is used for harvesters to query only data that has changed. If the provider does not have this information it should return the current date.
simplePliCTerm.definition.startValidateD: This is the first day that the record is valid for in the format YYYY-MM-DD.
simplePliCTerm.definition.endValidateDat: This is the last day that the record is valid for in the format YYYY-MM-DD.
simplePliCTerm.definition.countryCode: A two letter country code from the ISO specification.
simplePliCTerm.definition.language: The primary language of the data provided by the service. It is recommended to use codes defined by IANA, RFC 4646, 2 letter codes, no country
simplePliCTerm.definition.citation: Citation for the original source of the data. This data must be maintained an relayed by providers that harvest data from other providers.
simplePliCTerm.definition.trend: Whether the range of the organism is increasing or decreasing
simplePliCTerm.definition.rateOfSpread: How quickly the range of the organism is expanding
simplePliCTerm.definition.regulatoryList: The legal regulatory status of the organism
simplePliCTerm.definition.memo: An unsearchable field for providers to add anything else they think is important
simplePliCTerm.definition.publicationDat: Date the record was published in the format YYYY-MM-DD http://www.gisin.org/cwis438/websites/GISINDirectory/Tech/ProtocolSpecification.php#4.4.1.1
simplePliCTerm.definition.localityType: Defines the type of info in the Locality concept (city, park, cemetery, refuge, protected area)
simplePliCTerm.definition.locationValue: Value matching the code defined in the locality standard for the locality
simplePliCTerm.name.publicationDatePreci: Precisión de la fecha de publicación
simplePliCTerm.definition.publicationDat: Precision of the publication date. Unknown, Day, Month, Year
simplePliCTerm.definition.WhatImpact: What the actual impact is, for instance: Is it eating all riparian vegetation? Are their burrows destrying irrigation systems?
simplePliCTerm.definition.vector: The mechanism the organism is using to disperse
simplePliCTerm.definition.route: A textural description of the route the organism took from the FromCountryCode. If used, a LanguageCode must be specified. For example, this would be 'This species was brought over on a coal ship.'
simplePliCTerm.definition.Mechanism: Mechanism of introduction or impact to a new location
simplePliCTerm.definition.HabitatAndDist: Habitat and distribution of the species.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Habitats: General description of the enviroments where the species is found (landscape, ecosystem, macro or microhabitat).
simplePliCTerm.definition.HabitatUnstruc: Habitats element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.HabitatAtomize: In the DetailClass Attribute field a controlled vocabulary is recommended.
simplePliCTerm.comments.HabitatAtomized: Example: IUCN Habitats Classification Scheme, EUNIS.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Distribution: Information about the distribution of the species based on the studied specimens collection sites data.
simplePliCTerm.definition.DistributionUn: List of regions structured and categorized. A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
simplePliCTerm.definition.DistributionSc: List of regions structured and categorized. A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
simplePliCTerm.comments.DistributionScop: Example: Historical, Current, Restricted and Wide.
simplePliCTerm.definition.TemporalCovera: This field specifies temporal coverage, and allows coverages to be a single point in time, multiple points in time, or a range of dates.  Quick Reference: http://knb.ecoinformatics.org/software/eml/eml-2.1.1/eml-coverage.html#temporalCoverage
simplePliCTerm.definition.startDate: This field specifies the start date of temporal coverage
simplePliCTerm.definition.endDate: This field specifies the end date of temporal coverage
simplePliCTerm.definition.DistributionAt: Species geographical distribution. Distribution element in structured format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Catalogue: VC. The geographic entity according to ISO 3166 catalogue where the GeographicEntity is documented.
simplePliCTerm.definition.country: The name of the country or major administrative unit in which the Location occurs. It is recommended to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.
simplePliCTerm.definition.stateProvince: The full, unabbreviated name of the next smaller administrative region than stateProvince (county, shire, department, etc.) in which the Location occurs. DIVIPOLA
simplePliCTerm.definition.county: The name of the next smaller administrative region than country (state, province, canton, department, region, etc.) in which the Location occurs. DIVIPOLA
simplePliCTerm.definition.municipality: The full, unabbreviated name of the next smaller administrative region than county (city, municipality, etc.) in which the Location occurs. Do not use this term for a nearby named place that does not contain the actual location. DIVIPOLA
simplePliCTerm.definition.locality: The specific description of the place. Less specific geographic information can be provided in other geographic terms (higherGeography, continent, country, stateProvince, county, municipality, waterBody, island, islandGroup). This term may contain information modified from the original to correct perceived errors or standardize the description.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Endemic: Organism that lives exclusively in a particular territory and can not be found anywhere else.
simplePliCTerm.definition.EndemicAtomize: Endemic element in structured format. List of areas structured and categorized by the degree of safety.
simplePliCTerm.definition.EndemicTo: The concept is applied to one or several countries.
simplePliCTerm.comments.EndemicTo: Example: Giant panda (Ailuropoda melanoleuca (David, 1869) endemic to China. Quetzal Resplendent (Pharomachrus mocinno de la Llave, 1832) endemic to Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica and Panama.  Una lista de países o entidades geográficas superiores
simplePliCTerm.definition.EndemicIn: The concept is applied to an area either multinational or local.
simplePliCTerm.comments.EndemicIn: Example: Vicuña (Vicugna vicugna Molina, 1782) endemic to the Andean region. Manzanilla Real (Artemisia granatensis Boiss.) endemic to the peaks of Sierra Nevada (Spain).  Usar vocabulario para habitats y ecosistemas
simplePliCTerm.definition.DemographyAndT: Information concerning the demographic aspects of the species, as well as the conservation status.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Territory: Information, mostly associated to vertebrates, referring to the territorial extension of the individual or group in terms of its activities (feeding, mating, etc.).
simplePliCTerm.definition.TerritoryUnstr: Territory element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.ExtentOfOccurr: Area contained within the shortest continuous imaginary boundary which can be drawn to encompass all the known, inferred or projected sites of present occurrence of a taxon, excluding cases of vagrancy.
simplePliCTerm.definition.AreaOfOccupanc: Area within its 'extent of occurrence' (see EOO) which is occupied by a taxon, excluding cases of vagrancy. The measure reflects the fact that a taxon will not usually occur throughout the area of its extent of occurrence, which may contain unsuitable or unoccupied habitats.  Reference: http://www.iucnredlist.org/technical-documents/categories-and-criteria/2001-categories-criteria#definitions
simplePliCTerm.definition.PopulationBiol: Study of the variations in time and space, as well as in the size and density of populations, and the factors that cause such variations.
PopulationBiology element in text block format.
PopulationBiology element in structured format. A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
simplePliCTerm.definition.AbundanceData: Total number of individuals of a population.
simplePliCTerm.definition.DensityData: Population size in relation to a defined space unit.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Size: Size estimation, usually expressed as a range, of the populations of a species.
simplePliCTerm.comments.Size: Example: total population size is estimated between 200,000 to 400,000 ducks in its distribution area.
simplePliCTerm.definition.SexRatio: Relative number of males to females in a population.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Fecundity: Potential ability of an organism to produce eggs or young; rate of production of young by a female.
simplePliCTerm.definition.MortalityRate: Probability of dying; the ratio between the number of deaths in a given time interval to the number of subjects alive at the start of this interval
simplePliCTerm.definition.BirthRate: Production of new individuals in a population.
simplePliCTerm.definition.NumberIndividu: In case of having census data
simplePliCTerm.definition.AverageDensity: Average of the densities obtained for a population.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Recruitment: Rate that estimates the annual growth rate of a population based on the births, deaths, emigration and immigration.
simplePliCTerm.definition.PopulationGrow: Rate that estimates the annual growth rate of a population based on the births, deaths, emigration and immigration.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Emigration: Movement of individuals outside a population, or form one area to another
simplePliCTerm.definition.DescriptionLif: Percentage of individuals that belong to each life stage.
simplePliCTerm.definition.ProportionIndi: Percentage of individuals that belong to each life stage.
simplePliCTerm.definition.CarryingCapaci: Maximum population density defined by resources in the absence of predator and parasites
simplePliCTerm.definition.ThreatStatus: Information about the conservation status of the taxon.
simplePliCTerm.definition.ThreatStatusUn: ThreatStatus element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.ThreatStatusAt: Information about the status of the taxon in atomized format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.ThreatCategory: Description of the conservation status. A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Authority: Organism or institution that assess the status.
simplePliCTerm.definition.AppliesTo: Location where the status is used.
simplePliCTerm.definition.DirectThreats: VCR. Direct threats are immediate human activities or processes that have caused, are causing, or may cause the destruction, degradation, and/or decline of biodiversity targets (e.g., unsustainable fishing or logging). Direct threats stand for stress sources and proximate pressures. Threats can be past (historical), ongoing, and/or likely to occur in the future.
simplePliCTerm.definition.DirectThreatUn: DirectThreats element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Legislation: National and/or regional law or group of laws.
simplePliCTerm.definition.LegislationUns: National and/or regional law or group of laws.
simplePliCTerm.definition.LegislationNam: Word or phrase to designate the law or group of laws.
simplePliCTerm.definition.ProtectionLega: Description of the legal status. A controlled vocabulary is recommended
simplePliCTerm.definition.LegislationRea: The oficial document in which the user can read the legislation.
simplePliCTerm.definition.AppliesTo: Location where the legislation is used.
simplePliCTerm.definition.UsesManagement: Information concerning the ways in which species are used by people, including Folklore, Mangement and Conservation
simplePliCTerm.definition.Uses: Ways in which species are utilized by people, including Folklore. Also applied to Animals and Fungi.
simplePliCTerm.definition.UsesUnstructur: Uses element in text block format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.UsesAtomized: Ways in which species are utilized by people, including Folklore. Also applied to Animals and Fungi. Uses element in structured format. A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
simplePliCTerm.definition.SourceOfInform: Where does the observation come from? Reference citations should be given. Where appropriate, voucher specimen details should be provided (collector, number, date, herbarium) as well as details of the recorded informant (name, gender, approximate age, occupation, ethnic identity, locality and spoken language).
simplePliCTerm.definition.Use-Value: What is the plant used for, or what negative values does it have
simplePliCTerm.comments.Use-Value: Example: weeds affecting food production, poisons, environmental uses,...
simplePliCTerm.comments.PartUsed: Example: Entire plant, galls, seeds, bark,...  Reference: Acc. TDWG Economic Botany
simplePliCTerm.definition.Users: Acc. TDWG Economic Botany. The one who recognizes the value and/or use of the plant.
simplePliCTerm.comments.Users: Example: State ethnic group (tribe/caste /sect, etc.) with a language/dialect, in a locality/area.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Organisms: Acc. TDWG Economic Botany. Organisms which use the plant/plant parts (e.g . for forage , medicines) or are affected by the plant (e.g. by poisons)
simplePliCTerm.definition.VernacuarNameU: Acc. TDWG Economic Botany. The name of the taxon must be distinguished from the name of theplant parts, the names of any processing stages, and the final product name. Names used in trade should be identified. It should also be mentioned if any vernacular name refers to more than one taxon. The use of some names may be restricted to a time of year or occasion, or have sacred connotations. The language or dialect to which the names belong should be stated along with details of the ethnic group. Care should be taken with transliteration into the Roman alphabet; if a standard system exists, use it and note which one it is.
simplePliCTerm.definition.ProductionDeta: TAcc. TDWG Economic Botany. (where relevant). Give details of protection, cultivation, harvesting, yields, processing and storage methods used and take note of special tools, timing etc.
simplePliCTerm.definition.MeansOfApplica: Acc. TDWG Economic Botany. This is particulary relevant for medicines, poisons (e.g. insecticides), social drugs and some environmental purposes (e.g. fertilisers).
simplePliCTerm.definition.SeasonOfAvaila: Acc. TDWG Economic Botany. The season in which the plant is available/is used and, if relevant, the time of day.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Conservation-E: Acc. TDWG Economic Botany. Frequency record of plants, details of regeneration, sustainability or over-exploitation and any locally imposed bans on felling or harvesting.
simplePliCTerm.definition.UseTypeAtomize: Acc. TDWG Economic Botany. Type of use: traditional, modern, industrial or just a possible use
simplePliCTerm.definition.Economics: Acc. TDWG Economic Botany. Real or potential existence of trade in live plants, plant parts or derivatives and, if so, the trade scale.
simplePliCTerm.definition.RatingPopulari: Acc. TDWG Economic Botany. Assessment of the plant for its use and possible preference to other species, pointing out, in this case, which species are they. It is usefull to record the factors influencing any preference,
simplePliCTerm.comments.RatingPopularity: Example: rarity, inaccessibility, low quality or depleted source, ineffectiveness or difficult harvesting or processing requirements.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Properties: Acc. TDWG Economic Botany. Details of properties which influence its value for a specified purpose.
simplePliCTerm.comments.Properties: Example: Nutritional value for foods; occurrence of bioactive compounds for medicines / poisons; mechanical and physical properties of woods; nectar flow periods and flowering dates for honey plants; calorific values and burning qualities of fuels, etc.
simplePliCTerm.definition.Potential: Acc. TDWG Economic Botany. Potential increase in the use, cultivation or production or possibility of introduction in other areas or social groups.
simplePliCTerm.definition.ManagementAndC: Management: actions aimed at conserving or recovering species / Conservation: undertaken interventions designed to preserve species.
ManagementAndConservation element in text block format.
ManagementAndConservation element in structured format. Controlled vocabularyis recommended.
simplePliCTerm.comments.Actions: Example: IUCN Conservation Actions Classification Scheme
simplePliCTerm.definition.References: It represents the references that an element could have, in different formats.
simplePliCTerm.definition.id: Identifier (UUID) of the document. This identifier is set by the server on create and it cannot be modified.
simplePliCTerm.definition.profile_id: Profile id (UUID) of the Mendeley user that added the document to the system.
simplePliCTerm.definition.group_id: Group id (UUID) that the document belongs to.
simplePliCTerm.definition.created: Date the document was added to the system. This date is set by the server after a successful create request. This date is represented in ISO 8601 format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.last_modified: Date in which the document was last modified. This date is set by the server after a successful update request. This date is represented in ISO 8601 format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.identifiers: List of identifiers available for the document. The supported identifiers are: arxiv, doi, isbn, issn, pmid (PubMed), scopus and ssrn.
simplePliCTerm.definition.abstract: Brief summary of the document. maximum length 10,000
simplePliCTerm.definition.tags: List of user-supplied tags for the document. 50 each
simplePliCTerm.definition.type: The type of the document. Supported types: Revista, Libro, Sección de libro, Publicaciones de congresos, Documento de trabajo, Informe o reporte, Página web, Trabajo de grado, Documento legal, Archivo de audio, Artículo de enciclopedia, Video.
simplePliCTerm.definition.source: Publication outlet, i.e. where the document was published. Journal's title, Book's title
simplePliCTerm.name.title: Título
simplePliCTerm.definition.title: Title of the document.
simplePliCTerm.comments.title: Example:
simplePliCTerm.definition.authors: List of authors of the document, as person objects.
simplePliCTerm.definition.year: Year in which the document was issued/published.
simplePliCTerm.definition.volume: volume holding the document, e.g “2” from journal volume 2.
simplePliCTerm.definition.issue: issue holding the document, e.g. “5” for a journal article from journal volume 2, issue 5
simplePliCTerm.definition.pages: range of pages the document covers in the issue, e.g 4-8.
simplePliCTerm.definition.series: title of the collection holding the document (e.g. the series title for a book)
simplePliCTerm.definition.websites: Where the document was accessed from.
simplePliCTerm.definition.accessed: Date that the document was accessed. This date is represented in ISO 8601 format.
simplePliCTerm.definition.city: city where the document was published.
simplePliCTerm.definition.edition: edition holding the document, e.g. “3” from the third edition of a book.
simplePliCTerm.definition.institution: Institution in which the document was published.
simplePliCTerm.definition.editors: List of editors of the document. Like authors, this is a collection (array) of person objects, which include first_name and last_name (strings), as person objects.
simplePliCTerm.definition.keywords: List of author-supplied keywords for the document. 50 each
simplePliCTerm.definition.link: Link to the document’s page on the Mendeley website.
simplePliCTerm.definition.associatedPart: A party associated with the resource. Parties have a particular role.
simplePliCTerm.definition.role: Author: an agent associated with authoring a publication that used the data set, or of a data paper
simplePliCTerm.definition.AncillaryData: The AncillaryData element contains information that could be an image, an audio, a list of references, a list of agents, rights, licenses...related with the element that belongs. It`s a redefinition of DataObject element from EOL scheme.
simplePliCTerm.definition.license: License under which the resource is provided. To the greatest extent possible, the Encyclopedia of Life promotes an open-source, open-access approach.
simplePliCTerm.definition.rights: Statement of rights associated with the resource. Creative Commons licenses require the resource to be attributed 'in the manner specified by the author or licensor', and this is where that should be specified.
simplePliCTerm.definition.source: The URL of a web page which describes the resource.
simplePliCTerm.definition.bibliographicC: A bibliographic reference for the resource. Sufficient bibliographic details should be included to identify the resources as unambiguously as possible.
simplePliCTerm.definition.mediaURL: A URL reference directly to the media resource.
simplePliCTerm.definition.MeasurementOrF: The MeasurementOrFactClass has been created to include the information to know with which element MeasurementOrFact is related ,thorugh the element called 'relatedTo'. The classes is used to defined in a conceptual way a ComplexType of the xsd file. Description of the morphology of the taxon (size, weight, perimeter, length, volume, life expectancy, etc.). Makes reference to any meristic data of the species (wing span/maximum/228.6/ cm).
